_chemical.ChemicalName: Vinyl acetate monomer  [Acetic acid ethenyl ester]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Nashua Corporation Safety Policy
At Nashua Corporation we regard our people as our most valued asset.  To protect this highly valued asset, Nashua Corporation will:

-Provide the safest workplace posible
-Strive to exceed applicable safety laws and standards
-Strive to reduce and eliminate losses that can jeopardize the jobs of our people

I.  Sationary Source information

Address:  Nashua Corporation
               59 Daniel Webster Highway
               Merrimack, NH 03054 
Primary activity at site:  Coating of specialty papers
Regulated substance:  Vinyl acetate monomer
Use of regulated substance:  Used in the production of a polyvinylacetate based adhesive
Maximum Quantity onsite:  84,000 lbs

II.  Worst Case Release Scenario

-Scenario:  Instantaneous spill of 41,000 lbs of vinyl acetate monomer from a tranker truck during the unloading process.  The release would be limited to less than 2,196 pounds by the use of a spill containment pad and an underground containment tank system.  The release would take place over a 60-minute period.
-Under worst case weather, the vinyl acetate would travel 0.31 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public.

III.  Alternate Release Scenario

-Scenario:  A runaway reaction in the polymerization reator, containing 1,360 lbs (179 gals) of vinyl acetate monomer releases vapor into the venting system over a 120-minute period.  The vapor release would be limited to 400 lbs by a vapor condenser and a vent collection tank.
-Under worst case weather, the vinyl acetate monomer vapors would travel 0.11 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public.

IV.  Accidental Release Prevention Program

The facility is subject to the OSHA PSM rule.  The PSM program is an ongoing project at the facility with special attention given to release prevention by improved maintenance, training, and equipment upgrades wher and when warranted.

V.  Five Year Accident History

There have been no reportable

releases of vinyl acetate monomer in the last (5) years.

VI.  Emergency Response Program

The facility's Emergency Response Program relies on the Merrimack NH Fire Department and Clean Harbors, Inc. to respond to releases of hazardous materials.  The facility has a SPCC Plan, which documents notification procedures to be followed during and after a release of a hazardous substance.
